content.html:
I love reading RSS feeds. But sometimes words get tiring. Today is one of those days.

Luckily, I have a folder with a few very nice photo blogs that I fall into when I‚Äôm in such a phase.

I‚Äôve got the following blogs on there ‚Äì

@muan‚Äôs photos ‚Äì This has got to be one of my favorite photo blogs. The aesthetic is decidedly Instagrammy-personal. It‚Äôs a very direct peek into what Mu-An Chiou, a software engineer living in Taiwan, sees around her. She posts her pics as stories using the Open-Stories format and has an added layer of what is called the Open Heart protocol. It lets me hit the little heart button from within the RSS feed. That‚Äôs so cool! Of course, if you‚Äôre on her site, you can hit the little heart icon on her pics there. I love this setup much more than the horrible implementation by WordPress, so I hope someone takes the time to port this over so I can use it one day.

Manuel Moreale Instagram Style RSS Feed ‚Äì Manuel is a software dev in Italy. I love that he calls his photo RSS feed ‚ÄúInstagram style‚Äù. I don‚Äôt know if he posts the same to Instagram, but it‚Äôs interesting to see how that social network has influenced the way we think about photography. I loved the recent trip Manuel made to Umbria. He posted a link to an iCloud album and it‚Äôs gorgeous! In his own words (via email to me) ‚Äì ‚ÄúBut that‚Äôs Italy for you. There‚Äôs just too much to see.‚Äù

There are a few others in the list who are MIA ‚Äì Don‚Äôt Take Pictures, Licht Years. Would be cool if these blogs get revived at some point.

Through Mu-An, I recently discovered the Bring Back Blog directory and I‚Äôm slowly searching for and adding feeds that include photography (and some that don‚Äôt) to my feed reader.

But I‚Äôd love to hear from you, dear reader ‚Äì any blogs you‚Äôd recommend that I follow? I hold dearest personal, ‚Äúday in the life‚Äù photography. But I also love landscape photography that showcases the great outdoors and adventures of hiking and camping.

BTW, one of the things I miss the most is a short-lived project called bwrss by Giles Turnbull, which was black and white photography, delivered exclusively through the RSS feed and not visible anywhere else on the Internet. Giles, if you‚Äôre reading this, maybe bring it back? kthxbye.

content.html:
Ah, now this was real coffee! One shot of this in the afternoon and I was awake much later than I wanted to! üòÄ

After the previous Coffee Notes post, I got some really nice responses, mainly from the micro.blog community. There are a lot of discerning coffee drinkers out there and @Jean MacDonald, who is the Community manager at Micro.blog, linked me to a very nice table of the caffeine content in each of the Nespresso coffee pods. (future goal ‚Äì try the Palermo Kazaar one evening and see what that does to my sleep cycle!)

The Nespresso Ispirazione Firenze

So now I know that the previous coffee I had, the Livanto, had sixty four mg of caffeine per shot, while this new one, the Firenze, has only sixty three mg. However, it‚Äôs much more intense, at a nine out of thirteen.

That means a lot more kick, for sure! I experienced as much when I sipped my first cup. This coffee makes a nice amount of crema on top of the coffee and sits in the just dark enough on the dark roast scale to be exceptional.
Plus, the look is so royal! I love the purple of the pods. It gave a nice shine when I went to stand at my coffee workstation and it was a joy to pick up just one pod for my afternoon coffee.

I suppose it‚Äôs a (good) consequence of it being that much darker, that I can consume less of it.

I would say that I was pleasantly surprised by the combination of good taste and nice looks, but I sort of expected that when I pulled these out of the pack. However, it‚Äôs not all perfection. One of the pods failed to pierce properly and that resulted in plain (though a little dirty from my machine‚Äôs internals) water pouring out to my cup. I already had two spoons of sugar down there and I could see them quickly dissolving into the hot water.

Did I toss that water out? Nah. It just made for some watered down coffee. I liked it!

I did ‚Äúdiscover‚Äù something. When I usually make coffee, I take the milk directly from the fridge and set it to froth. One time however, my mother-in-law had already heated up milk for themselves and some extra was sitting in the saucepan. I took that and poured it out, taking with it some of the cream that settles on top when hot milk cools down.

That cream made for a really super frothy milk! It coated the insides of my glass and looked very nice. This will make for a beautiful coffee experience one day, when I pour super frothy milk into a glass cup instead of the usual ceramic ones I use. I double quotes ‚Äúdiscover‚Äù up there, because I sorta knew this beforehand, but haven‚Äôt used creamed milk in a while.

Maybe at some point in the future I‚Äôll make it a habit to either pre-warm and cool my milk, or add some whipping cream to my milk if I want that extra froth.

Anyways, final verdict on the coffee ‚Äì don‚Äôt have it after 4 pm, unless you want to be awake till 2 am! üòÄ

Shoutout to @pratik and @hawaiiboy over on microblog for not calling me a coffee snob.

content.html:
It almost feels wrong to begin Coffee Notes with Nespresso pods. After all, there are hundreds, if not thousands, of amazing coffee vendors all over the internet vying for our attention. They arguably even have better, cheaper product.

But I won‚Äôt belie Nespresso the quality of their products. After all, it‚Äôs their machine that I use to brew my coffee. So they‚Äôve got to know what works best with it, right?

Besides, I recently ordered a box set of Nespresso pods. So the first five reviews (probably, unless I get bored and order something different) are going to be of Nespresso pods. Here goes.

The Nespresso Livanto

Ah, this coffee was smooth. Too smooth! Those ten pods vanished fast. Partly because it‚Äôs a six on thirteen medium roast (point of order ‚Äì Nespresso‚Äôs rating system is out of thirteen.)

The taste was rich and smooth. I didn‚Äôt bother having it black, but I reckon it would have been creamy and absolutely drinkable. But throw in milk and sugar and it was quite glorious!

Since it was a medium roast, I ended up having it two at a time for my afternoon coffees. At three pods a day, I finished the box in about three days. I had to brew a Moka pot with my Indian coffee for the fourth day, to get through the afternoon.

At almost a dollar per pod (eighty cents, to be precise), these pods are at the expensive end of the range of OriginalLine pods I buy for my machine. Though, if I had a VertuoLine machine, I‚Äôd be averaging a dollar twenty five for similar pods. I seem to remember doing that research when considering which machine to buy. My Breville Nespresso Creatista won on that aspect.

I don‚Äôt have much else to say about this coffee. It was nice. It went fast. I‚Äôd definitely order more of it and keep it for light-coffee-drinking visitors. But usually, I end up serving them decaf or whatever other medium roast I have sitting around.

I will say ‚Äì I love the aluminum pods Nespresso ships. The color, the shape, the solidity of the pod, are all plus points in experience. These ones have a beautiful caramel color and I‚Äôm all for it!








Read about my Coffee Notes series in the introductory blog post here.

content.html:
In the tradition of every techie ever, I drink coffee daily. My average is about three cups a day. It used to be two cups, but then I went ahead and had a kid. So now it‚Äôs three to four cups a day.

I do not drink my coffee black. I find that my taste buds haven‚Äôt been ruined enough to enjoy black coffee. Milk and sugar is standard, though I experiment with things like caramel syrup, taro root powder, chaga mushroom powder, etc.

I drink essentially three types of coffee at home ‚Äì

  1. I own a Breville Nespresso Creatista machine and that‚Äôs my primary method of coffee intake. It takes Nespresso OriginalLine pods and spits out a coffee and steams the milk. Nespresso-compatible pods come with a rating system which seems out of 10, but the darker roast coffees are often 11 or 12. The rating system is supposed to be somewhat standardized, but I‚Äôve noticed that there‚Äôs a lot of variance. It seems that vendors, specially fly-by-night vendors on Amazon, just do whatever suits them. I‚Äôm ok with that. I‚Äôm not looking for a consistent coffee experience. If I wanted more caffeine, I‚Äôll just make another coffee. If I want less kick, I just add more milk and enjoy the coffee longer.
  2. I also use an IKEA Moka pot with this awesome South Indian coffee powder my friends gifted me. It has 40% chicory and that takes the taste in a whole different direction. I love that too! The Moka pot adds it‚Äôs own flavor profile. I don‚Äôt fill it up fully and the resulting coffee is somehow more bitter than if the pot were full. I love the darkness of the coffee on days when I want a real good jolt, and on days when I can‚Äôt run the machine as my kid‚Äôs sleeping.
  3. Lastly, I also enjoy Nestle Instant coffee, a holdover from my youth in India. This bottle is only available in Indian stores, though I‚Äôm sure grocery stores in the US carry their own type of instant coffee. The process is simple ‚Äì heat up some milk, toss in some sugar, toss in some coffee powder, and mix! A variation of this is to first milk sugar and coffee powder with hot water and whip it into a fine lather. Adding milk to that reveals a whole new world of joy.

While I may talk about numbers 2 and 3 at some later point, I‚Äôm going to focus mostly on number 1 for the foreseeable future in this series. I love buying coffee pods from different vendors on Amazon and sourcing them from my local grocery store. I‚Äôve had the machine for a while, so I‚Äôve actually drank a lot of variety, but I‚Äôm going to start fresh, and review each pod as I‚Äôm done with a box of it.

These will not be rigorous reviews. I‚Äôm not going for critique. Rather, it‚Äôs an exploration of my own ideas around coffee. Plus, I‚Äôve been aching to do a ‚Äúseries‚Äù on my blog and coffee being such a large part of our lives, it seems fitting to talk about it.

Let me know your thoughts on this in the comments section. I love to talk about coffee.
content.value:

content.html:
It‚Äôs been proven that quite a few species of animals and birds have intelligence, speech, empathy, critical thinking, and analysis levels similar to those of humans. Dolphins, birds, parrots, dogs, monkeys to name a few.

What if this is true for all major eras in Earth‚Äôs history where what we define as animals/birds roamed the world? (As in, not lower celled life).

Could that mean that various eras of dinosaurs or early humans evolved intelligence levels appropriate to go beyond just their survival ‚Äì problem solving, play, one-up-man-ship, etc.

But how can we figure this out? There would be some markers in the brains or bodies of current fauna to measure or perhaps only point to their intelligence. Would fossils allow us to find the same markers?

If I get a chance, I‚Äôll google around to find out more on this topic. If you know something about this, dear reader, please let me know? In the comments or on socials would be great!

Could that mean that various eras of dinosaurs or early humans evolved intelligence levels appropriate to go beyond just their survival ‚Äì problem solving, play, one-up-man-ship, etc. 
But how can we figure this out? There would be some markers in the brains or bodies of current fauna to measure or perhaps only point to their intelligence. Would fossils allow us to find the same markers?

content.html:
For about a week, I‚Äôve been suffering from an affliction. The ring finger of my write right hand has been hurting since Monday or Tuesday of last week. On Wednesday last, the pain became so much that I shuffled off to an Urgent Care center nearby to ask them to look at it. Before I did that though, I had to call to confirm that they have an X-ray machine. No point going to any kind of hospital facility if they just punt me to another location to get the definitive test to tell me if I‚Äôd fractured my finger. I also had to confirm that they‚Äôre in-network for my health insurance.

After the nurse had asked me a bunch of intake questions and the doctor had looked at it and ordered the X-ray, I was taken to a long, dark room with a focused X-ray machine aimed at where I would place the palm of my hand. The technician was Indian-origin and curious as to where in India I‚Äôm from. The doctor gave me a preliminary report that it doesn‚Äôt seem to be a fracture. He asked a nurse to set me up with a splint and send me off. I had a nice discussion where I learnt that instead of calling it crepe bandage, which is what it is, people in the US health industry refer to it by the brand name 3M gave to their product ‚Äì Coban.

The doctor came back and prescribed a strong painkiller, to be taken thrice daily for five days. (Spoiler Alert ‚Äì I didn‚Äôt take it thrice daily. I‚Äôm not that mad.) He also said that after a discussion with a radiologist, he‚Äôll inform me if there‚Äôs something that‚Äôs concerning, but in the meanwhile he also gave me a referral to an Orthopedic Surgeon at the other end of the world (downtown Redmond) ‚Äúin case the pain gets unbearable‚Äù.

Over the weekend, my parents insisted that I find the X-ray report and send it to them for analysis in India. I discovered that the X-ray slides themselves had not been uploaded (because, who actually needs patients to have the freedom to get a second opinion, right?) but a report had been uploaded that said that I have a ‚Äúpossible avulsed fracture‚Äù in the offended finger.

I started looking up Orthopedic doctors. One large facility in the area, which is apparently accepting new patients, told me that in truth they‚Äôre booked out till the end of February but will look to see if they can accommodate me. The other, a one-doctor outfit, told me on Monday to come over on Wednesday.

Today, in fear and anticipation, I landed at the Indian doctor‚Äôs offices (no, they were rented offices, one of three he operates out of. That business seems to be booming!) and was left waiting in the patient room (consultation room?) for a good fifteen minutes after the initial nurse intake. When the doctor came in, he tested my finger physically, then looked me in the eyes and said it‚Äôs a sprain.

I asked, ‚Äúare you sure?‚Äù

He replied, his deadpan eyes not giving even a glimmer of doubt, ‚Äúwe looked at the X-ray for a good ten minutes before we came in. There‚Äôs nothing in there to suggest that it‚Äôs a fracture. You don‚Äôt have a magical painless fracture. The fact that your pain is reduced and there‚Äôs no swelling around it‚Ä¶ Use your common sense.‚Äù

I‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt want to use my common sense. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm visiting a specialist. Whatever.

It‚Äôs not a fracture!

But I have a six week recovery ahead of me. I‚Äôve been told to buddy tape my ring finger with my middle finger if I can‚Äôt be careful in not further hurting the point which I‚Äôve sprained. I also have been downgraded from heavy painkillers to the Over the Counter stuff and ‚Äúonly if you need it‚Äù.

When I sat in the Lyft on the way back, I breathed a sigh of relief. The driver, in turn, told me that he‚Äôd just been to Hyderabad for two months for medical tourism for his father. He commented, ‚Äúthe people are so nice there! No one lies to you. They give you all your records in a nice file and let you know exactly what tests they performed and what the results are, in very simple language. I loved it there!‚Äù

Yeah. All common sense things to do in a good medical system.

He replied, his deadpan eyes not giving even a glimmer of doubt, ‚Äúwe looked at the X-ray for a good ten minutes before we came in. There‚Äôs nothing in there to suggest that it‚Äôs a fracture. You don‚Äôt have a magical painless fracture. The fact that your pain is reduced and there‚Äôs no swelling around it‚Ä¶ Use your common sense.‚Äù
I‚Ä¶ don‚Äôt want to use my common sense. That‚Äôs why I‚Äôm visiting a specialist. Whatever. 
It‚Äôs not a fracture!
But I have a six week recovery ahead of me. I‚Äôve been told to buddy tape my ring finger with my middle finger if I can‚Äôt be careful in not further hurting the point which I‚Äôve sprained. I also have been downgraded from heavy painkillers to the Over the Counter stuff and ‚Äúonly if you need it‚Äù.
When I sat in the Lyft on the way back, I breathed a sigh of relief. The driver, in turn, told me that he‚Äôd just been to Hyderabad for two months for medical tourism for his father. He commented, ‚Äúthe people are so nice there! No one lies to you. They give you all your records in a nice file and let you know exactly what tests they performed and what the results are, in very simple language. I loved it there!‚Äù
Yeah. All common sense things to do in a good medical system.

name: Finished ‚ÄúRousseau and Revolution: The Story of Civilization‚Äù audiobook

content.html:
For the last six months, I‚Äôve been on a journey. A journey through time. Specifically, from 1715 to 1789 AD. This journey has chiefly focused on one man ‚Äì Jean-Jacques Rousseau and one country ‚Äì France, as they both hurl towards the French revolution of 1789. However, surprisingly, the journey also touched almost everything else ‚Äì it covered hundreds of artists, writers, essayists, satirists, scientists, inventors, enterprises, kings, queens, books, pamphlets, lies, then-hidden truths, and ideas. It talked primarily of France, but framed its history by talking about every force outside of it, including Russia, the Turks, the many travails of Poland, and so many other factors that ultimately led to the revolution which shook the foundations of the Western World.

It also revealed to me how amazingly France participated in the formation of the United States of America, if only to spite the UK in doing so, and in the process destroyed it‚Äôs own wealth and legacy. But the silver lining shines through ‚Äì that revolution led to so much democracy and pushed the ideas of the Rights of people to the fore.

France, it‚Äôs history, and consequently, this book, are not without faults. The widespread support for slavery both within and without, the absurd conflict between Catholics and Protestants, which still boggles me, the constant wars with England, are all part of the history of France. The somewhat uneven-handed remarks and accolades to everything European being the ‚Äúbest‚Äù and the ‚Äúgreatest in the world‚Äù, the unnecessary descriptions of the visages of the persons described, and the somewhat abrupt ending, with only allusions to the excesses of the revolution, are all the faults of the book.

But I cannot thank the authors enough for giving me a springboard to leap off of. I have some semblance of an idea of where to start my next reading from, even though it‚Äôll be a while before I come back to anything regarding history. For now, I‚Äôve got quite a lineup of audiobooks to work through, from Andy Weir‚Äôs Project Hail Mary to a collection of short stories by amazing authors as Kate Chopin, Virginia Woolf, and Mary Shelley. I think I‚Äôll stay in the fiction lane for some time, till the call of history, philosophy, and the story of our civilization rises again.

Regarding the titular man ‚Äì Rousseau ‚Äì well, first of all, this book taught me how to write his name! It also told me of how terrible the person was in his personal life ‚Äì how cruel to his own children (none of whom he raised himself or welcomed into his home), how callous towards his long time lover and wife, how immature and suspicious of his friends. But also, how brilliant in his writing, how influential in thought, and how deeply rooted our current world is in his ideas. Apparently, he affected everything from both our major systems of early childhood education ‚Äì kindergarten and montessori, to innumerable philosophers, writers (Tolstoy, Byron, Shelley, Keats, Thoreau, Kant, Schopenhauer), and the Romantic movement. He even made it fashionable to climb mountains and explore the great outdoors in Europe as well as to have gardens that look more natural than manicured perfections. In an upcoming blog post, I argue that the writings matter, not the writer. As much as I‚Äôve come to despise the man, this is true for Rousseau ‚Äì he was an influential writer and thinker, even though he was a horrible little man.

Book timeline ‚Äì Jul 22nd 2022 -> Jan 24th 2023

Format ‚Äì audiobook

Length ‚Äì 57 hours 22 minutes

Tonight‚Äôs iPhone wallpaper is the Pale Blue Dot, where everyone ever has lived and died, mostly unnoticed by the rest of the solar system, let alone the galaxy or the universe.

name: The lack of Gutenberg editor support is irritating now

content.html:
If you want to, you can use a Jetpack feature called Post by Email to send your WordPress posts via your favorite email client. There‚Äôs wide support for setting the title, tags, categories, as well as adding attachments and using shortcodes. But if you do‚Ä¶

the post arrives as a Classic Block

Source: Yes! Post by email lives (and finding hidden Jetpack modules) ‚Äì CogDogBlog

Much as I enjoy using Jetpack with WordPress, I dislike that they‚Äôve embraced the Gutenberg blocks editor completely, but not adapted to it. If you send a post to it via email or from other apps on iOS or through the Save as Draft feature, it‚Äôll invariably get saved as a Classic Block and then must be edited to convert to individual blocks. This is not so problematic, as the end user sees a somewhat consistent output. But it sure is irritating UX.

I would love it if Jetpack could work on making this consistent and going all in on Gutenberg.
content.value:
If you want to, you can use a Jetpack feature called Post by Email to send your WordPress posts via your favorite email client. There‚Äôs wide support for setting the title, tags, categories, as well as adding attachments and using shortcodes. But if you do‚Ä¶
the post arrives as a Classic Block
Source: Yes! Post by email lives (and finding hidden Jetpack modules) ‚Äì CogDogBlog
Much as I enjoy using Jetpack with WordPress, I dislike that they‚Äôve embraced the Gutenberg blocks editor completely, but not adapted to it. If you send a post to it via email or from other apps on iOS or through the Save as Draft feature, it‚Äôll invariably get saved as a Classic Block and then must be edited to convert to individual blocks. This is not so problematic, as the end user sees a somewhat consistent output. But it sure is irritating UX.
I would love it if Jetpack could work on making this consistent and going all in on Gutenberg.

content.html:
I find it strange and interesting when people tend to their ‚Äúdigital gardens‚Äù. Try as I may, I cannot treat this blog as a sort of self-referential wiki. A blog to me is a log, a journal. It starts afresh every time I begin writing in it. Perhaps if I wrote daily, it would make sense to me how everyone is always linking to their own posts?

But the fact is, I don‚Äôt do any real discovery on my own blog. I write, and I move on. I don‚Äôt forget, per se. After all, sometimes I link to my own posts. But largely, the process of writing here is one of growth. I write as it‚Äôs my way of thinking, or feeling, or seeing what my present looks like. When it‚Äôs written, it‚Äôs the past. We don‚Äôt dwell on that here.

In that sense, this is more a flowing river of thought than a digital garden. Whatever metaphors go with that, apply to this blog. It‚Äôs also why the interface irks me so. I want a sort of chat interface instead of this massive writing space. I want my blog to look like a journal, instead of published writing. But, since the frontend is not for me, but for others, and since others have told me that they like this interface, I don‚Äôt do the work of finding a new theme. Independent Publisher is a good theme and it does the job. Yes, I can customize it a bit more, but why? To what end? I don‚Äôt even look at the posts that often. Just read them once in a while when I discover them through stats or search. In those moments, I find the interface sufficient. Thus, it doesn‚Äôt feel like I should blow up the feel of the entire blog just for how I‚Äôm feeling right now. That‚Äôs counter-intuitive to what I said at the beginning of this post, but so be it.

Sometimes I envy the micro.blog interface. It‚Äôs a river of thoughts. This is not true for the individual blogs, since they sort of act exactly like this blog, though with smaller font sizes. But the main ‚Äúhome‚Äù interface is what I sometimes wish I had. But when I start writing on desktop, I tend to write longer sentences and in paragraphs. So the point of having a small writing and reading space is lost. It‚Äôs only when I‚Äôm on mobile that I feel the cumbersomeness of this interface. Also, I kind of do have that interface ‚Äì on my LiveBlog. It‚Äôs got exactly that dirty sort of input mechanism that I‚Äôve designed to be minimal and a front-end that‚Äôs obnoxiously simple. Only 30 days worth of posts are displayed on a page, due to a technical limitation in the backend code that I can‚Äôt bring myself to overcome. I keep wondering if I should look into extending that web app so that it doesn‚Äôt just post to twitter, nice.social, and beta.pnut.io but also here, to this blog, as well as mastodon.

Mastodon‚Äôs API is apparently very painful to deal with. Of course, I‚Äôd be using some prebuilt PHP library to do that work, but it‚Äôs still supposed to not be easy. So, I found a solution in a web app called moa.party, which cross-posts from twitter to mastodon. Good enough. I don‚Äôt want to move the entire work of cross-posting to third parties, otherwise I‚Äôd use pipedream to just do the whole thing instead of dealing with PHP. But I know this solution. It‚Äôs never been perfect, but it works well enough. I don‚Äôt want to touch it beyond this, nor do I have the time to do so.

Speaking of mastodon, I‚Äôve been thinking and if I were ever to move off my liveblog and live on mastodon, I‚Äôd like to do so at a cost of $5-10/year. That‚Äôs yearly, not monthly. I don‚Äôt do pic/video uploads, I don‚Äôt do excessive posting and I‚Äôm not famous to drive a lot of traffic. I reckon a server with a couple hundred users paying that much would break even. Maybe I‚Äôm wrong. I‚Äôd love to talk to some folks running mastodon servers and figure out what their costs are like. I‚Äôve not yet found any resources for mastodon servers by pricing. If something like that doesn‚Äôt exist, I‚Äôd like to create it and put it out there. People should be able to find servers not just by interest and community but also by cost.

Mastodon is making microblogging like email. It‚Äôs letting people create their own servers and run them as they want. The cross-pollination features are strong, but also have (apparently) great controls, to the point that some servers have or will decouple from mastodon.social to present freeloaders like me (but basically spammers and outrage pundits) from getting in the face of folks who just want a good time online within their own communities. At some point, some big entity will start a mastodon instance that will centralize power and wipe out competition (a la gmail) but till that happens, the social web is molting and it‚Äôs good. Services like Pixelfed are riding this wave and doing to photo sharing what mastodon is doing to microblogging. If all of these can begin to act like email, that‚Äôs all the better for end users like me. We don‚Äôt think about our email provider. It‚Äôs just there in the background. We used to not pay for email. Now we do. We don‚Äôt pay for social, till we begin and that‚Äôll be fine too.

I‚Äôm thoroughly enjoying finding new audiobooks and sources of audiobooks, even though I know I won‚Äôt be able to get to most of them any time soon. I have quite a backlog in audible and Libby, yet I‚Äôve recently discovered Open Library (run by Internet Archive) and through them, reminded of LibriVox. I have bookmarked a few audiobooks on there, like Dubliners by James Joyce. Maybe I‚Äôll get to it at some point. But for now, I‚Äôm very happy listening to Rousseau and Revolution by the historians Durant. I also snagged a deal on audible and got Project Hail Mary by Andy Wier for a significant discount and I have an audiobook credit that‚Äôll expire with a few days, which means I‚Äôll have to get some other book too. I also have Kate Chopin‚Äôs The Awakening on my radar, after seeing its presence in the Netflix show 1899.

Plus, I‚Äôve found that since I do all my listening through my iPhone, if there‚Äôs no good app to support LibriVox listening on there, I probably won‚Äôt use it a lot. But I‚Äôm most likely wrong. Why wouldn‚Äôt there be a good set of third party apps for LibriVox on iOS, if not first party?

I came across an old browser bookmark ‚Äì a website called My Writing Spot for the epynomous app. The website is dated, the app is no longer available, but the domain keeps getting renewed every year and the hosting seems to be working fine (albeit without SSL). There‚Äôs a webapp (hosted on appspot) which can be logged into with a gmail account, but I don‚Äôt trust the permissions to muck around. From what I can see, the app was active on both iOS and Android between 2010 and 2014, with support even for Nook and Kindle (and even, it seems, Dropbox sync). There are tweets from around 2015 talking about how the sync functionality is broken. At first, I didn‚Äôt understand why the website would even be up. But perhaps it‚Äôs part of the developer‚Äôs portfolio and a deadlink is a bad idea in the freelancing world. But why the heck is the webapp up and running?? Surely it‚Äôs costing them money to host that?

Anyways, it‚Äôs an interesting glimpse into the heyday of apps, when it was painful to develop for iPads as well as iPhones (and the apps were separately priced), and when things like ‚ÄúIncredible iPad Apps for Dummies‚Äù existed.

It‚Äôs also a glimpse into the web of that decade. You can share the website on StumbleUpon (replaced by their new product Mix) and Delicious (domain now redirects to Delicious AI, an app for converting your pet photos into art using image-to-image), and you can read a blog that was last updated May 26, 2012.

content.html:
There‚Äôs a beautiful blanket of snow outside, so it‚Äôs a good time to review how the year went.

I read thirteen books this year, though ‚Äúread‚Äù is a loosely based concept now. A large part of my reading nowadays is graphic novels, audiobooks, and web novellas.

But I do consider all of this reading. It‚Äôs the transmission of ideas based on the written word, even if it‚Äôs accompanied by pictures (or largely based on them) or read by someone into my ear. So, I‚Äôve read thirteen books this year.

Of these, only two were print ‚Äì Earthlings, and Incredible Doom vol 1.

Nine were digital ‚Äì The Missing Piece Meets the Big O, ‚ÄúTeen Titans: Raven‚Äù, Cyclopedia Exotica, Turtles All the Way Down, Wallace the Brave, Bloom, Big Mushy Happy Lump, The Tea Dragon Society, and The Boy, the Mole, the Fox, and the Horse. Of these, The Tea Dragon Society was in webcomic form while the rest were eBooks from the Seattle Public Library.

I also got in two audiobooks ‚Äì My Year of Rest and Relaxation and Figuring

Not bad considering this is also the year my Little One was born and who is right now scurrying across the floor of our apartment, looking for things to attack!

I read most of the graphic novels in the middle of the year and in Fall, when my reading seemed to have slowed down to a snails pace. Getting a few small or quick reads under my belt made me feel better and allowed me to begin reading some larger works, which I‚Äôm still working through.

Right now I‚Äôm reading the web novel Worm and listening to Rousseau and Revolution, and these are both long enough that I‚Äôll not be done any time soon. I‚Äôm halfway through Rousseau‚Ä¶ and Worm‚Ä¶ well, by the author‚Äôs own admission, Worm is ‚Äúroughly 1,680,000 words; roughly 26 typical novels in length (or 10-11 very thick novels)‚Äù, so I‚Äôm a ways away from closing that book. Perhaps these will be added to my finished list next year.

This year, I depended a lot on Seattle Public Library. I loved discovering audiobooks, graphic novels, and eBooks from them. Whatever I really wanted to read and wasn‚Äôt available immediately there, I found on audible or Thriftbooks.

I own a physical copy of Figuring. But the book is massive and the writing dense. It really gave itself to being an audiobook in a perfect way. The ideas that came from it though‚Ä¶ I wish I could bookmark every page of the book! Figuring deals heavily with the Transcendentalists and women authors, philosophers, and scientists, and introduced me to the concept of Salons. The book wanes with the works of Rachel Carson, chiefly Silent Spring, and ends with the tragic death of Margaret Fuller in a shipwreck off the coast of New York.

From there, I tried to read Silent Spring, but lost interest very quickly. The writing is interesting, but I was already being pulled in other directions. I‚Äôve learnt a new term this year ‚Äì DNF ‚Äì Did Not Finish. People seem to use it like ‚ÄúI DNF‚Äôd this book‚Äù.

So, here‚Äôs a list of books I DNF‚Äôd this year ‚Äì

  • Silent Spring
  • Braiding Sweetgrass
  • All the Sad Young Literary Men
  • Under the Sea Wind
  • Plato and a Platypus Walk into a Bar
  • Philosophy ‚Äì a Visual Encyclopedia
  • South
  • The World of Edena
  • Representative Men
  • Thus Spoke Zarathustra
  • Thank You for Arguing
  • Enola Holmes Graphic Novel, Book 1
  • Accidentally Wes Anderson
  • The Map of Knowledge
  • Abstract City
  • Reality+
  • Irish Fairy Tales
  • All the Names They Used for God

Let me know if you, dear reader, would like links to any of the above. Since I didn‚Äôt finish them, I didn‚Äôt bother linking to them.

All of these were from Seattle Public Library, and more specifically, from the Overdrive/Libby catalog. There are yet others in my Kindle app and iBooks app which are waiting to be read, but I didn‚Äôt include them here as they‚Äôre just, sort of, suspended in animation, waiting to see if I pick them up again. Perhaps I will. There‚Äôs one of definite interest to me ‚Äì GoÃàdel, Escher, Bach : an eternal golden braid ‚Äì but it‚Äôs very likely that I won‚Äôt read it, because it‚Äôs in a format that‚Äôs not easy to consume on my iPhone and there doesn‚Äôt seem to be an audiobook for it. So perhaps I‚Äôll add it to next year‚Äôs DNF list. Let‚Äôs see.

So that was it ‚Äì my year in reading. It was a good year. I peaked (in tracked reading) in 2017, (though I‚Äôm sure I read a lot more in my childhood, but who doesn‚Äôt?) and this year has come in second in number of books. Though, moving to graphic novels means that my overall page count is lower. But does it matter? I don‚Äôt think it does. It‚Äôs the quality of ideas that matters. I‚Äôve got a lot more out of small books like A Room of One‚Äôs Own, Siddhartha, and The Last Question than any normal length novel. What I‚Äôve got out of massive tomes like War and Peace and Figuring is a different thing, since it‚Äôs more of learning an entire way of life than one or two ideas. Graphic novels like Wallace The Brave, Bloom and Big Mushy Happy Lump are fun reads, and it‚Äôs important to just relax and enjoy a story too. Incredible Doom and Cyclopedia Exotica challenge your assumptions but in an easy way and I can‚Äôt thank the authors enough for the effort they‚Äôve put into these worlds.

Data Courtesy TheStoryGraph
content.value:
photo of library with turned on lights 
There‚Äôs a beautiful blanket of snow outside, so it‚Äôs a good time to review how the year went.
I read thirteen books this year, though ‚Äúread‚Äù is a loosely based concept now. A large part of my reading nowadays is graphic novels, audiobooks, and web novellas.
But I do consider all of this reading. It‚Äôs the transmission of ideas based on the written word, even if it‚Äôs accompanied by pictures (or largely based on them) or read by someone into my ear. So, I‚Äôve read thirteen books this year.
Of these, only two were print ‚Äì Earthlings, and Incredible Doom vol 1.
Nine were digital ‚Äì The Missing Piece Meets the Big O, ‚ÄúTeen Titans: Raven‚Äù, Cyclopedia Exotica, Turtles All the Way Down, Wallace the Brave, Bloom, Big Mushy Happy Lump, The Tea Dragon Society, and The Boy, the Mole, the Fox, and the Horse. Of these, The Tea Dragon Society was in webcomic form while the rest were eBooks from the Seattle Public Library.
I also got in two audiobooks ‚Äì My Year of Rest and Relaxation and Figuring
Not bad considering this is also the year my Little One was born and who is right now scurrying across the floor of our apartment, looking for things to attack!
I read most of the graphic novels in the middle of the year and in Fall, when my reading seemed to have slowed down to a snails pace. Getting a few small or quick reads under my belt made me feel better and allowed me to begin reading some larger works, which I‚Äôm still working through.
Right now I‚Äôm reading the web novel Worm and listening to Rousseau and Revolution, and these are both long enough that I‚Äôll not be done any time soon. I‚Äôm halfway through Rousseau‚Ä¶ and Worm‚Ä¶ well, by the author‚Äôs own admission, Worm is ‚Äúroughly 1,680,000 words; roughly 26 typical novels in length (or 10-11 very thick novels)‚Äù, so I‚Äôm a ways away from closing that book. Perhaps these will be added to my finished list next year.
This year, I depended a lot on Seattle Public Library. I loved discovering audiobooks, graphic novels, and eBooks from them. Whatever I really wanted to read and wasn‚Äôt available immediately there, I found on audible or Thriftbooks.
I own a physical copy of Figuring. But the book is massive and the writing dense. It really gave itself to being an audiobook in a perfect way. The ideas that came from it though‚Ä¶ I wish I could bookmark every page of the book! Figuring deals heavily with the Transcendentalists and women authors, philosophers, and scientists, and introduced me to the concept of Salons. The book wanes with the works of Rachel Carson, chiefly Silent Spring, and ends with the tragic death of Margaret Fuller in a shipwreck off the coast of New York.
From there, I tried to read Silent Spring, but lost interest very quickly. The writing is interesting, but I was already being pulled in other directions. I‚Äôve learnt a new term this year ‚Äì DNF ‚Äì Did Not Finish. People seem to use it like ‚ÄúI DNF‚Äôd this book‚Äù. 
So, here‚Äôs a list of books I DNF‚Äôd this year ‚Äì 

Silent Spring
Braiding Sweetgrass
All the Sad Young Literary Men
Under the Sea Wind
Plato and a Platypus Walk into a Bar
Philosophy ‚Äì a Visual Encyclopedia
South
The World of Edena
Representative Men
Thus Spoke Zarathustra
Thank You for Arguing
Enola Holmes Graphic Novel, Book 1
Accidentally Wes Anderson
The Map of Knowledge
Abstract City
Reality+
Irish Fairy Tales
All the Names They Used for God

Let me know if you, dear reader, would like links to any of the above. Since I didn‚Äôt finish them, I didn‚Äôt bother linking to them.
All of these were from Seattle Public Library, and more specifically, from the Overdrive/Libby catalog. There are yet others in my Kindle app and iBooks app which are waiting to be read, but I didn‚Äôt include them here as they‚Äôre just, sort of, suspended in animation, waiting to see if I pick them up again. Perhaps I will. There‚Äôs one of definite interest to me ‚Äì GoÃàdel, Escher, Bach : an eternal golden braid ‚Äì but it‚Äôs very likely that I won‚Äôt read it, because it‚Äôs in a format that‚Äôs not easy to consume on my iPhone and there doesn‚Äôt seem to be an audiobook for it. So perhaps I‚Äôll add it to next year‚Äôs DNF list. Let‚Äôs see.
So that was it ‚Äì my year in reading. It was a good year. I peaked (in tracked reading) in 2017, (though I‚Äôm sure I read a lot more in my childhood, but who doesn‚Äôt?) and this year has come in second in number of books. Though, moving to graphic novels means that my overall page count is lower. But does it matter? I don‚Äôt think it does. It‚Äôs the quality of ideas that matters. I‚Äôve got a lot more out of small books like A Room of One‚Äôs Own, Siddhartha, and The Last Question than any normal length novel. What I‚Äôve got out of massive tomes like War and Peace and Figuring is a different thing, since it‚Äôs more of learning an entire way of life than one or two ideas. Graphic novels like Wallace The Brave, Bloom and Big Mushy Happy Lump are fun reads, and it‚Äôs important to just relax and enjoy a story too. Incredible Doom and Cyclopedia Exotica challenge your assumptions but in an easy way and I can‚Äôt thank the authors enough for the effort they‚Äôve put into these worlds.
